note: In Switzerland, cryptocurrencies are considered private wealth assets and are subject to Wealth Tax.

Private investors are not subject to Capital Gains Tax on cryptocurrency holdings; however, Wealth Tax applies based on the total value of assets, including cryptocurrencies, as of December 31 each year.
Each canton in Switzerland has its own Wealth Tax rate, which typically ranges between 0.1% and 1%.
Income from cryptocurrency activities, such as mining or staking, is considered taxable income and is subject to Income Tax.

Income Tax rates in Switzerland are progressive and vary by canton, with federal rates up to 11.5% and combined federal, cantonal, and municipal rates reaching up to approximately 40% in some regions.
Purchasing cryptocurrencies with fiat currency, holding them, and transferring between personal wallets are non-taxable events.
Capital losses from cryptocurrency transactions cannot be offset against other income, as capital gains are not taxable for private investors.
Taxpayers are required to report their cryptocurrency holdings and any related income in their annual tax returns, maintaining detailed records of all transactions.
The deadline for tax returns in Switzerland varies by canton but generally falls between March and April each year, covering the previous financial year from January 1 to December 31.
The Swiss Federal Tax Administration (FTA) has the authority to track cryptocurrency transactions and holdings, especially under international agreements on data sharing and anti-money laundering.
Penalties for failing to report cryptocurrency income can include fines, interest on unpaid taxes, and in severe cases, imprisonment.
It's essential for investors to stay informed about the evolving tax regulations in Switzerland to ensure accurate reporting and compliance with the law.
